column1: When will Lebanon's parliament give a vote of confidence to a new government?
column5: ['Before 1 December 2020', 'Between 1 December 2020 and 31 January 2021', 'Between 1 February 2021 and 31 March 2021', 'Not before 1 April 2021']
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
It is close to the deadline and no sign of this occurring.
no sign of this happening and very close to deadline
Time update
No talks have come forward that indicate advancement.
Revising down given time remaining; no indication this will happen before April 1, 2021.
Considering that it is currently March 18 and no vote has been announced to be anytime soon, it likely will not occur before April 1.

I wonder if this can start to spin fast enough to finally end in bin 3 after all: "Lebanon's Hariri says priority to form government and re-engage IMF" https://www.arabnews.com/node/1827681/middle-east
Lebanon’s Inaction Means Prolonged Depression, Says World Bank

Things seem to be getting worse in Lebanon. The nation is scaling back food subsidies and will gradually raise gasoline prices to save dwindling foreign reserves, the caretaker finance minister said. Few things energize a citizenry in the Middle East more than a cutback on subsidies. It will be important to watch this over the next few weeks to see if it causes any major changes to the structure of the government. But for now, I'm adjusting the likelihood nothing gets down by 1 April.

Decrementing due time remaining despite the fact this article talks about the current caretaker prime minister threatening to resign in order to pressure the sides to come to an agreement. Though the collapse of the Lebanese pound may exert additional pressure, it still seems unlikely the new government will form before April 1.
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1813386/middle-east
There is very little happening in Lebanon that would lead me to believe anything is changing the current deadlock. I'll adjust this by 1% per week over the remaining time of the forecast.
News reporting continues to indicate that things are not progressing well in Lebanon. I'm adjusting my likelihood by about 10% to account for the lack of movement.

With calls for UN involvement now being made while the President and Prime Minister remain entrenched the chance of proposing and voting on a gov't in 30 days remains very slim. https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/fpm-tells-hariri-govt-must-be-formed-in-lebanon/ar-BB1e4iJH

Recent articles suggest by-elections by end of march, then vote of confidence (still not crystal clear on if the vote of confidence can happen before by-elections). https://www.arabnews.com/node/1812881/middle-east https://www.the961.com/parliamentary-by-elections-end-of-march/
Lebanese government wins confidence vote as protesters clash with police outside parliament
Just over two weeks have passed since my original forecast with very little movement. I'm adjusting by a few points to account for the lack of activity.
French entreaties continue to appear futile. Prime Minister and President appear to remain as far apart as ever.

Qatar won’t give Lebanon any aid unless it swiftly forms a new government to manage its worst economic crisis in decades, its foreign minister said during a visit to Beirut. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-09/qatari-foreign-minister-to-visit-lebanon-in-bid-to-end-deadlock ============== and so are the Multinational organizations ....
Parties continuing to declare more tension and separation without even meeting or talking.

Decrementing because President Aoun and Prime Minister Hariri remain light-years apart and no indication Prime Minister Hariri will be removed or step aside. Securing World Bank funding takes pressure of national government to take internal measures to form government. Some glimmer of hope through indications of impending visit by French President Marcon. An ameliorated US posture to Hezbollah requested and supported by the French could ease some pressure on Lebanese politicians to compromise, however Hezbollah challenges are now deep seated in political leaders minds.
Tremendous amount of turmoil, distrust, and frustration amongst stakeholders: https://www.arabnews.com/node/1797286/middle-east

This was tough to establish a base rate for. It looks like the last time parliment gave a vote of confidence to a new government in Lebanon was in February 2020 (https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/protests-lebanon-ahead-cabinet-vote-confidence-68902041). Prior to that it took them a year to form a government (2019) after having their first parlimentary elections in nine years (2018) (https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/political-instability-lebanon).
I have a general idea of what a vote of confidence consists of, but not in Lebanon, so I need to do a bit of research!

Lebanon’s political process appears to change quickly and often, making it difficult to establish a base rate of how long it takes new Prime Ministers to form their governments. In 2009, it took the Prime Minster (PM) eight months to win parliament’s vote of confidence. Conversely, the previous (PM), appointed in December 2019, took only two months. The current PM, Saad Hariri, was appointed 22 October 2020. Simply averaging the two available data points (two months and eight months) would suggest parliament will give a vote of confidence to Hariri’s new government by 31 March 2021.

The government formation process is being held up by both personal insults and political disagreements PM designee was insulted by video footage of President calling PMd a liar. The primary policy difference is President's insistence that Interior and Justice ministries not be controlled by the PMd's party. Most variables are internal to the country (sectarian politics), but two external variables could influence the speed of parliamentary approval- pressure from the World Bank or France. I believe neither will have significant effect on the process. One outcome is the Pmd and President agree on a slate of ministers and another outcome is that PMd withdraws from forming a government. It's unlikely he will withdraw and unlikely outside pressure has any great effect on the formation process. There's been almost no progress in January and President has upper hand in blocking PMd candidates because the population's expectations for resolution are low.

Outside View: A vote of confidence appears to happen after regular election cycles, the last was in Feb 2020. The PM resigned after the port blast last August, and Mustapha Adib, the PM-designate, couldn’t do it and stepped aside in 26 Sep 2020. The former PM Hariri is now attempting to form a government, but faces significant opposition.
Still massive disagreement among major players. https://www.arabnews.com/node/1797286/middle-east
It is possible that the delay in the Lebanonese formation of a new government is do in part to incompetence and in part to geopolitical issues.
https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/economy/story/Mediators_fail_to_thaw_AounHariri_diplomatic_freeze_to_solve_Lebanons_cabinet_crisis-SNG_198424807/
https://thearabweekly.com/walid-jumblatt-describes-deep-divide-between-aoun-hariri https://www.arabnews.com/node/1796836/middle-east

Little time remaining so I'm depleting by end of January, seems highly unlikely a cabinet is formed and approved by parliament in that timeframe. There are some positive recent news articles, so I'm keeping higher confidence in February to March. But I thought that about earlier categories too, so leaving plenty of uncertainty for the last bucket. The process so far has appeared to be highly dysfunctional.
https://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Local/2021/Jan-20/516489-lebanese-pound-up-with-prospect-of-govt-formation-revival.ashx
Wow!
It's getting a bit itchy for the second bin...
All the recent news seems negative, no signs of progress. Significantly lowering the likelihood of this happening before end of January.

The obtuseness of the press releases makes it difficult to determine any meaningful discussion, however the proposed cabinet member list has been stalled for the past month. With Lebanon finances estimated to hold for up to 6 months I will stay at approximately 50/50 with a slight increase in the near-term based on new cycle of meetings.

There is no sign of progress in forming a government and in recent years it has taken 15-20 days from the formation of a new government to the Vote of Confidence. Also, the central bank announced that it has reserves for 6 more months. Therefore, I see it as unlikely that a government will be formed in the next 15 days.

“The economy and financial, banking system is in shambles, social peace starts to crumble down, security incidents on the rise, the edifice of #Lebanon is shaking in its fundaments. And political leaders seem to wait for Biden. But this is Lebanon, not the USA,” [U.N. Coordinator for Lebanon Jan] Kubis said in a tweet. http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/278076-kubis-to-politicians-this-is-lebanon-not-the-usa
Switching buckets 2 and 3, before January 31 seems slightly more likely to me, but very uncertain because it's been a mess so far.

Increasing later months a bit, news this morning is saying things are stalled.

There are contradicting sources when a new government will form some say it will form this December http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/277433-report-lebanon-will-likely-see-new-cabinet-before-macron-s-visit other claim it will only form after Biden has taken office https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20201124-us-undermining-formation-of-lebanon-government/. It is confirmed that the Prime minister and the President are in talks about the nomination of the ministers https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2020/Dec-07/515132-aoun-hariri-relaunch-govt-formation-process-discuss-names-of-ministers.ashx . Also the rising economic and food crisis puts pressure on the political parties to form a new government because financial aid is linked to the condition of a new government. On the contrary the vote of confidence has taken longer for every new government. 2009 it took only on day where 2019 it took 20 days.
Hariri began consultations with the president on a draft cabinet list. Increasing odds of success in December a bit.

The one political driver which would encourage empaneling a cabinet before 31 Jan is the incoming US administration. If Biden is in WH on 20 Jan, will the Lebanese cabinet want to have all this hashed out before then? Seems to me Iran and Saudi Arabia would want to have their slates as clean as possible before engaging with the new administration and settling political disputes in Lebanon would fit that mold.

Decrementing 1 Dec-31 Jan category by 6 for passage of time. Still appears to be an impasse between the political elites with no positive indicators at this time.

It seems they are close and very far apart, depending on what you are looking at. From a Lebanese political situation, its seems they could be close. From a geo-political situation, the American election could have push the issue into Janauary after a Biden inaugration.

Moving 40% back to my original average base rate analysis for forming a government (3-4 months). Reserving 20% that Hariri falls out and the process starts over again with someone new.

"The Lebanese Parliament has removed the major obstacle preventing a forensic audit of the country's central bank, a week after international firm Alvarez & Marsal terminated its contract. Parliament passed a recommendation on Friday that the Banking Secrecy Law should be waived for a future forensic audit that should be carried out not just for the central bank but for all state institutions." [...] "His [French President Emmanuel Macron's] message coincides with France’s announcement that it will host a video conference with international partners on December 2 to discuss humanitarian aid for crisis-stricken Lebanon." https://www.arabianbusiness.com/banking-finance/455233-lebanon-clears-way-for-new-central-bank-audit-amid-rogue-nation-fears
Updating since time is running out on 1 Dec. No real updates in the past month.

Significantly downgrading my optimistic view from a couple weeks ago. Govt formation by 1 Dec seems a near impossibility at this point. No significant headway has been made to form a cabinet, let alone hold a vote of confidence. Next month's aid conference co-chaired by Macron and the UNSG may put additional pressure on Hariri to get a government formed, but my level of confidence isn't particularly high. It is unclear from this outsider's perspective exactly what will break the logjam.
Depleting before Dec 1, time is nearly out and no news of progress from a brief search. Before January 31 looks most likely I think.
It is well to remember that "vote of confidence" is a technical term and does not reflect anybody's actual feeling of confidence in anybody else. Stay tuned.

"BEIRUT, Nov 26 (Reuters) - Lebanon's caretaker finance minister said on Thursday that central bank foreign currency reserves currently stand at $17.9 billion and that there are discussions about reducing subsidy spending as critically low reserves dwindle. Ghazi Wazni said in an interview with local broadcaster LBCI that he supported gradually rationalising spending on subsidies until a new government is formed that enacts long-demanded reforms to unlock foreign financial assistance. Lebanon is grappling with a deep economic and financial crisis that has hammered the currency, spread poverty and prompted a sovereign debt default. An official source had told Reuters that only $800 million in foreign currency reserves were available for subsidising key imports such as fuel, wheat and medicine until the end of 2020."[...] "Wazni said the formation of a new government was direly needed to address the deepening crisis. He said unemployment in Lebanon had reached more than 40%." https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/lebanese-finmin-says-he-supports-reducing-subsidy-spending-2020-11-26
I guess decision makers are aware of all that.

Hmm, should have stuck with my original forecast and worked from there. Too many factions with conflicting interests at play to overcome inertia. Lesson learnt.

I had raised the likelihood of forming the cabinet before Dec 1 based on more optimistic news reports the other week. However, there has been very little movement since those reports. Now, press is reporting that some Lebanese politicians are dragging their heels because they want to look to the results of U.S. elections. Sanctions against Bassil also seem to be a more pressing concern for certain parts of the government.

Based largely on @TDHesslink 's analysis of the outside view/base rate of how long it typically takes to get a new government in place, and other teammates' info on factors such as the intransigence of the different factions and the fact that it looks like US sanctions have made certain factions dig in their heels even further, I'm revising my overall forecast to push the likelihood of a new government forming to a date after April 1.
-10 on before December 1, not much good news recently as far as I can tell.

Aoun and Hariri cannot agree to Christian representation in the cabinet and talks, it appears, are stalled. Worse yet, the sides appear to be digging in deeper, so the outlook for renewed negotiations by the end of the month are grim.

It seems like there has been some progress, however the factions are still haggling over ministerial assignments which has been a significant sticking point in the past. I'm upping my forecast for government formation before December 1, but it is by no means a sure thing.
-30 on before December 1, sounds like it's getting bogged down by the different factions. Still seems like they might be close.

Updating based on 11/2 reporting that the sides are close to a compromise on an 18-minister cabinet. The distribution of portfolios seems to be the key sticking point now. It sounds like Berri and Ibrahim are playing a more helpful role.

Beirut, Nov 2 (Prensa Latina) Optimism about the rapid establishment of a Government in Lebanon has vanished overnight due to the insurmountable demands by political parties, local media commented on Monday.

http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2020/Nov-01/513780-govt-formation-hits-snags-as-rival-factions-dictate-demands.ashx. Factional infighting has resumed. Seems like the issues are not quite as "solved" as I previously thought. Furthermore, it seems I was putting too much stock in the announcement of a govt formation rather than the actual parliamentary vote of confidence. I'm still leaning toward that happening in the next 4 weeks, but my confidence has waned a bit.

@SEHolmes01 read that as well. Looks like Hezbollah refrained from naming Hariri, but has tacitly endorsed his return to form a government. They may also help to pull the Christian Party across the line to get a deal done. @ssbyrum I like the approach with heavy emphasis on the front, or it doesn't happen for awhile; especially if Hariri isn't the guy.
Updating based on reports that Hizballah and Basil seem to be blocking progress and there has not yet been a meeting scheduled with President Aoun.
- No new information available.

The current PM was only tapped due to a small majority. Lebanon has historic issues with forming a government. Thus, this will happen quickly due to shared interests of restoring governance in the wake of the blast and political upheaval in Beirut, or it will follow traditional trends of much longer coalition building.

http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/276099. Looks like Hariri has made significant headway with the competing parties toward ID'ing ministers and forming a govt. There's still a chance that the deal can fall apart (Aoun still needs to hammer out cooperation w/ Hizballah), but the lack of direction and initiative seems to be dissipating. Thus a big swing in my optimism about government formation in the next month
Good points by my team. I am adjusting. This may be happening sooner than I expected. France's push and a smaller field are the primary drivers of my change.

As expected, Hariri was tapped to form a government. I'm not sure this changes the calculus of the players involved, particularly Hezbollah. Forecast remains the same. I'm actually giving a slight nod to Hariri's chances by not reducing the odds of government formation before December 1 due to the passage of time since my original forecast.
-French PM is holding fast to aid for reform deadline of 1 Dec. - Selection of Harri provides opportunity for interim technocratic government.

Updated based on the news that on 10/22 Hariri was tapped to form a government. Given his political connections, he may be able to form some sort of technocratic government, but no bets on how long it would last or if it could accomplish anything.

Macron might well have pulled this off. But a new PM is only the beginning. As others have pointed out, it often takes months to assemble a coalition. The intense French diplomatic effort is an outside factor which could speed this process.
Got a new PM backed by a majority, seems likely in the near future.
Seems to be looking more likely a government is formed by the end of the year.

"Barring last-minute snags, and despite opposition by the two main Christian blocs, former Prime Minister Saad Hariri is set to be designated to form a new government this week, exactly a year after he resigned under the pressure of a nationwide popular uprising that erupted against the worsening economic conditions and the country’s entrenched political elite.
- The removal of Prime Minister Saad Hariri from the race consolidates support from the two main Christian parties in Lebanon, namely the Free Patriotic Movement (FPM) and the Lebanese Forces.

updating based on new info. @mwackers @TDHesslink @slink08. Delayed consultation decreases chance of vote before December 1. However, looking through the articles is still appears that Hariri enjoys a consensus amongst most of the parties. I think you will see his name pop up again as a contender by the end of the month, making vote between December and January possible. The international and domestic pressure on Lebanon to get this done grows more urgent daily.
Keeping prediction. Some recent events that seem negative regarding a positive outcome before December 1st 1. delayed consultation 2. major christian party not supporting Hariri

The elimination of Hariri as a viable candidate somewhat dampens my optimism (https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-lebanon-crisis-patriarch/top-christian-cleric-urges-lebanese-leaders-to-agree-on-government-idUKKBN2730BG), but I still find it likely that a cabinet can be formed by 31 Mar.
Next round of discussions start delayed until Oct 28th.
https://thehill.com/opinion/international/520645-lebanese-revolution-comes-full-circle-with-the-first-anniversary

In a recent conversation with a Lebanese Army Officer, naming of a Prime Minister is supposed to occur by November. This is predicated on whether or not the ministers are named first. If this happens, a vote of confidence will then occur and Lebanon still has the financial incentives from France urging this to happen sooner rather than later. As of 13 Oct, the President has summoned all parties in to discuss so that is progress. Adjusting my initial lengthy timeline based on history to more short term evaluation given contemporary context.

Lebanon typically struggles to form a government quickly based on the power sharing arrangement between religious factions. According to the economist as of early 2019 (https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments) the country has had 2.5 years out of the previous 13 without a government. However, the reemergence of Hariri as a potential PM following Adib's stepping down seems to indicate hope for a somewhat quicker solution in this case. Still, any of a number of parties (including Hezbollah) could exercise its veto stymieing progress. International pressure by France could encourage action to ensure financial guarantees. BL- there are a lot of competing interests and time pressures, but that hasn't seemed to make for quick government formations on avg in the past, so I expect a long timeline here as well.

- Base rate: Government formation routinely takes several months in Lebanon. - The current prime minister, Hassan Diab, resigned August 10 following the explosion at the Beirut port. Diab continues as a caretaker. Parties have not agreed to a new government despite an attempt to form one around Lebanon ambassador to Germany Mustafa Adib. Adib stepped down on September 26 amid the deadlock over government formation. It's difficult to see how the incentives for the parties to form a government will change before the end of the year. - Lebanon's confesionalist power sharing structure gives Hezbollah a veto over any new government. - France and the United States have been publicly at odds over Lebanon. French President Macron has dangled debt relief (IMF, other donors) in return for reform in Lebanon. However, the United States has taken a much harder line against any negotiations with Hezbollah (and Iran). Hezbollah may believe the negotiating environment will be more favorable under a Biden administration. With Biden leading in US polls, Hezbollah will wait to see who wins the election.
This week's news will be critical to see if a government before Dec 1st can be created.

Based on the dire economic situation and the contingency of European aid on a new government Lebanon must install a new government as soon as possible. Usual political shenanigans could delay the formation until past December but it is not likely.

The closest base rate I can determine for time for parliament to vote on a new government is approximately 10 months. However it appears, parliament votes more frequently than just during election cycles. Lebanon has three factors for forming the current government - pending debt payments, French political involvement, and post explosion corruption charges. All point to a significant delay in forming a government. French's involvement is to avoid religiously affiliated political parties from participating in a caretaker government. Absolutely no indication that will be achievable or supported by a parliamentary vote. Debt payments were defaulted in March 2020. I have been unable to find when the next payment is due, however IMF has suspended negotiations on a debt payment since July due to unsatisfactory progress and now without a government to negotiate with there will be no progress. This could be a driver for getting a government formed, however meeting IMF demands to relieve debt payment - most likely ending a large number of subsidies - will likely not be supported by the citizens or parliament. The recent explosion has resulted in the arrest of 25 officials however no investigation results have been released and protests indicate citizens continue to demand change to historic political system that allowed mismanagement to reach point of the devastating explosion. The next election is not scheduled until 2022, but an early election could be called. Lebanon's last scheduled election was delayed over 3 yrs so any call for early elections will likely not result in a gov't getting formed in the next 6 months.

- Parliament is divided between 18 religious groups. - Lebanon has spent 2.5 years of the past 13 without a government - Lebanon formed a state of emergency on 13 Aug -Macron warned that if real reforms don’t happen, including in the banking sector and at the central bank, France could impose punitive sanctions on the ruling class. - President Michel Aoun has called for binding consultations with members of parliament this week to name a new prime minister, after appointing a PM a government still needs to be established. Seems to be a 1-3 month process. - Current economic conditions and threatened sanctions will increase the need for the establishment of a new government.

Since 2008, the seven changes of parliament have taken anywhere from two weeks to 9 months for an average of four months to gain a vote of confidence for a new government. The nine month span was most recent in 2019. The deteriorating circumstances in the country will provide greater incentive for Lebanon's government and the international community to see this through. Lebanon needs the new parliament to secure much needed international assistance. @SE_Meyer Also, President Aoun and Speaker Berri's willingness to meet with former Prime Minister Hariri (who is willing to re-take the seat) is promising. If it is Hariri, it took him five months on his first attempt and nine months on his second attempt to get a vote of confidence.
"Hariri to meet Aoun, Berri before deciding on premiership bid"/"BREAKING: Hariri says talks with Aoun over new govt. 'encouraging' "
"Ex-Prime Minister Saad Hariri Thursday declared that he was open to taking on his former position once again, saying that he was a “natural candidate” to head the next government."

Given how complicated the Lebanese political landscape is, for now I'm just trying to come up with a base rate. The last time there was a major turnover of power, it took 3 months from Saad Hariri's resignation as PM in Oct 2019 until a new government was seated in Jan 2020.

Per Lebanon's President, consultations for a new PM will start 15 Oct. This is after the last attempt to form a government failed in September. The political leaders seem to be highly partisan and not talking to each other. Macron has continued to put pressure on the nation to form a government. Due to the dire economic/banking situation, the Lebanese people could either pressure the parliament to work together or devolve into civil war. A lot of unknowns. The distribution of seats based on religion created a highly fragmented parliament which makes it difficult to form a government, but the fact that funds are being withheld until a government is formed could force a government to form in order to prevent a civil war.

If history in Lebanon is any indicator, the last government took 2.5 years to elect a President, 9 years to elect the Parliament and 12 to pass a budget. Sectarian divides are deeper than ever which will make this task a long one. Despite the French President's ultimatum of withholding financial aid or imposing sanctions on the leading elite over the next three months, the economic crisis will not be enough to motivate a vote of confidence in a new government.

Next important date is October 15 where there will consultations to see who will be tapped as a potential prime minister to try and corm a government. https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-lebanon-crisis-government-idUKKBN26S0TO
The deep sectarian lines drawn in Lebanon make it so that transitions of power and the forming of new governments will likely take a long and tumultuous path before giving a new vote of confidence.
Lebanon is not historically fast moving in this arena. Will the current turmoil and unrest speed the process along? I don't' think it will. There seems to be little trust in the governing elite.

- Outside view – historically it has taken Lebanon many months to form a cabinet (2019 – eight months, 2014 – ten months. As of December 2018, Lebanon had spent 2.5 out of the last 13 years without a government). - It’s highly unlikely Lebanon will be able to form a cabinet before November 3 U.S. presidential elections. Pompeo has criticized Macron’s engagement with Hizballah and the U.S. imposed sanctions on Hizballah allies. U.S. is not supporting France’s diplomatic push. - The Iranian and Saudi backed factions have dug in. Plus, the West has preconditioned billions of dollars of aid on the creation of the government and subsidies of basic goods could soon end, leading to economic disaster and possibly more unrest.
Progress seems stalled, and it seems without strong international pressure, this may not advance quickly.
Upping the before December bucket and December to January buckets a bit based on other comments showing that it's unusual for government formation to take exceedingly long.

Apparently it took about 9 months in early 2019. A few months again around late 2019. But Macron has been putting increased international pressure on the Lebanese politicians to form a government and fix the ongoing issues in the country which have been exacerbated by the explosion. Hard to say what will happen, I think there's a decent chance it happens in the next few months but lots of uncertainty.

With the Shia mini-state within Lebanon having no interest in co-operating, plus the continuing decay of Lebanon's unique power-sharing arrangement between the different ethnic and religious groups, the outlook is bleak. Macron might have to pull off a diplomatic coup worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize to achieve this before the end of year. Hope he does so because things could well worse before they improve. Economic assistance will pour in regardless of when a government is formed and this could well mean self-interest trumps the national interest.
Forming a new government typically takes approximately 4 months in the past ten years, with a typical range of 1 to 5 months.

The French colonial heritage, and thus the EU, forces them to urge political classes to resign and pave way for a new, less corrupt order in Lebanon. Since assistance money is attached to a conforming reform effort, those problematic ties between rich families of Beirut steering the country in their self interest for decades, and the government will have to loosen quickly if they don't want to forego more than one billion EUR in a assistance money, as far as I heard.
